intro: Campanula antirrhina, commonly known as the bellflower, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Europe. It features showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from blue to purple, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. The plant has opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs, and it thrives in well-drained soils in full sun to partial shade. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and is also used in traditional medicine. Campanula antirrhina is known for its ability to naturalize and spread through rhizomes, making it a persistent and resilient plant in suitable environments.
